comment.author: 29350288@N06
comment._content: "After seeing Charlotte Davies do her posing act at Hammerstein's theater -- an act that included "Statue of a Maiden", "September Morn", "The Bath", "The Dancer", and the suspect-sounding "The White Slave", -- Variety's "Jolo" dismissed the routine as "merely  a vulgar display of robust undraped femininity"  -- "Blue Vaudeville: Sex, Morals and the Mass Marketing of Amusement, 1895-1915" by Andrew L. Erdman, page 193.

comment.author: 92284803@N00
comment._content: Here's a Google Books source about Charlotte Davies, from The Green Book Magazine.

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content:
Another review:
"Charlotte Davies is still defying the changeable Spring weather at the Victoria.
Such confidence in a gold bracelet; deserves its reward.
Indeed, there is little about Miss Davies to commentupon. But it was sheer enthusiasm to call her poses living " pictures."
-Dramatic Mirror, May-June 1915.
